title: Windows PC's pixel = ?# em units
content:
What is the # of em units to match a PC’s pixel? ( Not a mac’s ).

The reason I ask is that I have font which uses 1000 UPM & has 100em unit pixels ( vector not bitmap ).

This font looks nice & crisp at 10 pt - on a mac.

But it does **not** look crisp at any size on the PC. It has been true type hinted ( which helped alot ) but it seems quite clear - it just isn’t fitting the grid.

Any ideas?
author: Eben Sorkin

comments.content:
The _default_ resolution on Windows systems is 96dpi, but many people tweak it. Otherwise, 7.5 points should in theory render your font crisply.

In the not-too-distant future, operating systems will automatically query the resolution off the display using Extended Display Identification Data (EDID), so a “pt” will, once again, be 1/72” or thereabouts.
What if I wanted to tweak my font for PC users? What # of em Units should I use? 75em?

Testing in photoshop with a 96 dpi image rather than a 72dpi seemed to bear this idea out . :-) Yea! - I haven’t been able to test it on a pc yet. Obviously this issue is only relevant if you are looking for a match \*onscreeen\* - the printed fonts would not match with this soultion. Still, that is what I was looking for. Thanks!
i just saw the result & yes. it worked perfectly. Thanks ralph!
